title: Obesity and Nutrition Research
content: Research interests include obesity and nutrition, quantitative genetics, clinical trials, statistical and research methodology, and research rigor and integrity. A lot of time is spent getting into what is known and what is not known about obesity and also the science of obesity. In particular, focus is on the science of nutrition and nutritional epidemiology. Most of the measures that we have in place from a public health perspective are probably not founded in any scientific basis.

title: Obesity Crisis Recognition and Impact
content: Obesity rates have been steadily increasing in westernized industrialized countries since the 1700s. A wake-up moment occurred in the early ‘90’s with the NHANES III study, which showed a big jump in obesity levels. This got everyone’s attention and words like epidemic started to be used, especially for childhood obesity. The public health policy and environmental perspective started to shift in the mid-90’s. People began to think about prevention and children and the overall environment, the political, economic, social, food marketing environment we live in.

title: Sloppy Science in Obesity Research
content: As interest in obesity research grew, the science became sloppy. It brought about a dilution of the rigor of the field intellectually. It became a lot more of opinion, a lot more of advocacy. In the absence of rigorous evidence showing what worked, people are saying, “This seems like it ought to work”.

title: Genetics of Obesity
content: Smart people understood there is a genetic component to obesity. Any rancher could have told you a hundred or more years ago that there’s a genetic component. We can selectively breed animals for being thinner or fatter. It’s prima facie evidence.

title: Genetic Influence on Body Mass Index
content: For monozygotic (or identical twins) separated at or nearly after birth, the concordance is around 0.8. This suggests a strong genetic influence on body mass index. This was further supported by studies published in the International Journal of Obesity and Related Metabolic Disorders in 1996, which showed the heritability of body mass index among an international sample of monozygotic twins reared apart. However, it's also noted that the rearing of the home does have an influence, but it’s not huge.

title: Historical Approach to Obesity Treatment
content: Historically, when genetics play a role in disease, pharmacologic therapy makes sense. However, there was a disconnect in the early ‘80’s when it was understood that genetics plays a role in obesity but medical tools were not being used. Most of the focus was on developing tools to help people reduce energy intake. This is still the case today. Surgery and drugs mostly help people reduce calorie intake.

title: Use of Pharmaceuticals in Obesity Treatment
content: In the early 90’s, a few people started using pharmaceuticals to treat obesity. Fen-phen is a drug that came up and caught people’s attention. Fen-phen is a nickname for two drugs used in combination, phentermine and fenfluramine. Phentermine is a drug that was and still is approved by the FDA for the treatment of obesity. Fenfluramine is a selective serotonergic reuptake inhibitor, which originally was used for depression and people realized sometimes those drugs (SSRIs) cause weight loss. However, fen-phen was found to produce a certain valvulopathy and further investigation made it clear it was the fenfluramine component, not the phentermine component that did that. So fenfluramine was withdrawn.

title: Surgical Options for Obesity
content: Surgical options for obesity began to be used and as more and more surgeries were performed, people got better at doing them, mortality rates went down and efficacy went up. The Swedish obesity study from Lars Sjostrom in Sweden showed that surgery reduced the mortality rate. Surgery had very powerful effects on obesity. It was clearly a life-saving and a beneficially, life-changing treatment.

title: Obesity Paradox
content: The 'Obesity Paradox' refers to the observation that people at the very thin end also die earlier than people in the middle, just as people at the very heavy end die earlier. Additionally, when people are sick or injured, obese people often live the longest. This is true even though obesity is associated with increased mortality rate or decreased longevity.

title: Understanding Obesity and Mortality
content: It’s very difficult to disentangle cause and effect. We can observe lots of associations, but it’s just hard to know what to make of all of these associations, and what’s causal. There are multiple hypotheses that are consistent with the data. What if obesity makes it more likely that you get a major illness or injury? Could this be why obesity is associated with a risk of early mortality? Once you get a major illness or injury, does being heavier (more obese) reduce your risk of dying from it?

title: BMI and Aging
content: Under a mathematical model, the point of BMI, the nadir of that bathtub shape concave upward curve, should keep moving to the right as you age, which is exactly what it does. The average American might gain about a pound a year. For an average height, about 6 or so pounds might be a BMI unit. And so that might mean that over 6 years, you’d be about one BMI unit heavier. And that’s not too far off from how the nadir moves. It’s almost as though your weight is increasing to keep you at the nadir, which is an interesting speculation.

title: Interpreting BMI and Mortality Data
content: Peter wonders if there is a risk that we are looking at confounders here? Could affluence be a confounder? When body composition is taken into account, do you see the same thing? Some people have a BMI of 30 and fall into the obese category even though they only have 15% body fat; instead they are incredibly muscular. How do we reconcile, one, the potential confounders of that type of an analysis with this layer of granularity in the data that looks at adiposity versus lean mass?

title: Confounding Factors in BMI Analysis
content: There are a lot of possibilities for confounding, cigarette smoking was one of the early ones. Smoking makes you thinner; smoking kills you earlier. You’ve got to throw out the subjects who die early, because subjects who die early may have been sick. And sickness makes you thinner and makes you die earlier, that is a confounder. It has since been proved mathematically, that throwing out these confounders is not a good thing to do.

title: Effect of Weight Loss Interventions
content: The bottom line, we don’t know; and the real important question then is, what’s the effect of intervention? So if you say weight loss is going to increase longevity (that’s the question) well, how are you going to achieve that weight? What are you going to do to get that? If it’s surgery, then what’s the effect of surgery? If it’s a GLP-1 agonist, what’s the effect of a GLP-1 agonist, et cetera? We are starting to see that some of these things do prolong life: surgery, SGLT-2 inhibitors, GLP-1 agonists, and so forth.

title: BMI and Body Composition
content: BMI is a measure of mass divided by stature. It was developed back in the 19th century by Adolph Quetelet, who was a Belgian astronomer, epidemiologist, statistician, mathematician, a brilliant guy. BMI doesn’t really take into account body composition. The NBA center would have a BMI greater than 30 and yet look how strong and fit that person is. What physician in their right mind would diagnose them as obese?

title: BMI as a Health Metric
content: BMI is a useful tool for epidemiologic research and some simple physiologic research and some simple clinical trials, it’s not a perfect clinical tool. For the average person, BMI works okay. Where a BMI of 20 to 25 is about perfect, 25 to 30 is overweight, 30 to 40 is obese. Then morbidly obese kicks in at some point. The shape of that curve is not the same in every age, race, and sex group. It does seem that the right side (the part where you’re getting too high in BMI and risk is going up) seems to occur a lot earlier among people of Middle Eastern and East Asian descent.

title: Ethnic Differences in BMI and Disease Risk
content: Some people are skinny fat, they have a BMI of 26 but have metabolic syndrome, tons of visceral fat, very little muscle mass. This is a different phenotype than perhaps what the model was built on. How much is the metric that we use for BMI validated in other ethnicities? Some groups have more visceral fat than the others for any given body mass index; and therefore it adjusts the curve.

title: Superior Tools for Measuring Obesity
content: Peter uses other tools to measure obesity; DEXA scans provide 4 points of information: 1) % body fat 2) Visceral fat (VAT, visceral adipose tissue) 3) Bone mineral density 4) Appendicular Lean Mass Index, a measure of muscle mass. It also provides information about subcutaneous fat, but that doesn’t seem to matter because it is incredibly genetic and relatively uncoupled from metabolic health. VAT, the visceral adipose tissue seems to be much more tightly correlated to what we see when we look at more sophisticated biomarkers of insulin sensitivity and metabolic health, and any evidence of liver fat.

title: Using BMI Data for Actionable Steps to Combat Obesity
content: With BMI we can accurately plot out the histogram of exactly what the BMI is by age and by demographic and all those things. Questions: Are people in Indiana more or less healthy than people in Kentucky? And are they more or less healthy than the average American? What can we do to improve their health? Could everybody become healthier? Could we extend the life of the average person in the state of Indiana by three years? What would the intervention need to be? These questions lead to more complicated problems.

title: Why Maintaining Weight Loss is More Challenging Than Losing Weight
content: This is a tough one; there is probably no single explanation. You can approach this from an evolutionary perspective, biochemical perspective; you can think about mechanisms. From the evolutionary point of view, for a long time, the meme was it’s the thrifty gene hypothesis from James Neel. The idea is that animals/ humans throughout evolutionary history have been on the brink of starvation. They did anything they could to preserve energy. When given the opportunity to get more energy, they ate as much as they could, while they could. Now in the modern environment, most of use over consume.

title: Sexual vs Asexual Reproduction
content: In asexual reproduction an organism makes a copy of itself; it reproduces all of its genes. Sexual reproduction requires a partner. The offspring has roughly 50% of the genetic material of one parent and 50% of the other. The organism only copied half of itself so it didn’t win as much as if it copied itself entirely. Sexual reproduction is a way to keep up with the microbes in your body.

title: Thrifty Gene Hypothesis
content: The thrifty gene hypothesis argues you need to be selected to get food when you can. If you’re not getting enough food you may not be big enough to win the battle for mates in a polygyny physical combat mating system. That may select for wanting to eat more. If women get too thin, they stop menstruating. They may not die of starvation, but their reproductive fitness goes down.

title: Food Safety and Cooperative Living
content: Food safety is another idea; this is supported by Gary Beauchamp, from Monell Chemical Census Center. Back in time before refrigeration and a modern, safe food supply, every time you ate something you were potentially exposed to microbes and toxins. Eating less meant less exposure. But now with a safer food supply, this pressure is less. Cooperative living is another angle; as a group it’s a bad situation if the members are so hungry all the time they are willing to kill each other for the last bite. It would be good to have some satiety mechanisms to preserve social order.

title: Nutritional Epidemiology
content: Epidemiology is married very closely with statistics. Without statistics you can’t really do epidemiology. There are 2 camps, 2 ends of the spectrum of views on nutritional epidemiology. One camp says there is absolutely nothing wrong with epidemiology, nutritional epidemiology. It is a masterful tool that provides exceptional insights without which we would be lost. The other camp says this is a tool that has probably reached its peak of utility. The epidemiologists should probably focus on other problems outside of nutrition now.

title: Limitations of Nutritional Epidemiology
content: Findings of nutritional epidemiology often don’t hold up very well. There are huge issues with confounding. There are huge measurement problems. Many people say the status quo is not okay. More change is needed than some minor fine-tuning. Reform is needed. Observational studies can be improved. There are better studies. Co-twin controls use identical twins and we randomly assign each to a different group. Observing interventions, even if they are not assigned at random, is a much stronger design than just asking people how far away do you live from a grocery store.

title: Measurement of Food Intakes
content: Many people incorrectly perceive the problem to be a measurement issue. They agree that measurement of food intakes is a big problem but think everything else is fine. When the measurement is near perfect, everything is not fine. We need a greater level of honesty. An honest epistemic humility would say, “I really might be wrong, and here’s all the ways I might be wrong that I and others should test going forward”.

title: Obesity and Nutrition
content: Obesity and nutrition are often connected to many emotional things. We all have that everyday experience and have to make decisions every day. We make these decisions and then we may want to justify them; we may need to believe they’re good. We may mistake our experience for expertise. When you get into any field where people have everyday experience, people have very strong feelings and often will opine quite aggressively in the absence of data.

title: Obesity Epidemic and Treatment
content: Some pretty exciting pharmacologic things have come along. Semaglutide (a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist) is a remarkable drug. Amazing progress has been made on the surgical front and pharmacological front. It’s not clear why progress hasn’t been made on the nutritional front. A diet has not been found that reliably causes sustained weight loss.

title: Public Health Approach to Obesity
content: The one area where we are not making progress, and we aren’t yet on a good path, is with this public health community, school based, community based, policy based approach. We continue to ignore the data. We keep saying the same old suggestions that people have been trying for decades. And that when you really look at the data, these have at best not been shown to work, and at worst been shown to not work.

title: Promising Interventions for Obesity and Public Health
content: General education, especially for girls and women, leads to lower BMIs, lesser rates of obesity, and lesser diabetes than less education. Some studies in Europe of policies where someone puts in a policy and it effectively gives a cohort of people more education show this results in that cohort, less obesity, especially among women. The Moving to Opportunity Study funded by The Department of Housing and Urban Development took families who lived in so-called poor neighborhoods, and they randomly assigned them either to a control group, where they basically got nothing, or to a group where they received housing vouchers; but the housing vouchers required that they moved to less poor neighborhoods. What they found years later in follow up is that there was less obesity and diabetes in those assigned to move to the less poor neighborhoods and given the financial wherewithal to do so.

title: Addressing Obesity and Diabetes
content: If given the federal budget to make an impact on obesity and diabetes, the funds would be divided into 4 pots. One pot is going to be surgery, and it’s going to be both providing it and continuing to study it. The next one’s going to be pharmaceuticals, both providing it and continuing to study it. The third pot is going to be some general education, maybe general wellbeing, safety, security, starting in early childhood to see whether that alone is enough. And then the fourth pot would be basic research, basic science questions.

title: Reproducibility in Science
content: Reproducibility and Replicability in Science. The idea is that we must make things better. There might be some things that are getting worse, but on average, there’s a lot of evidence that things are getting better. Science is better and more rigorous than it’s ever been in history. But we also see all the flaws and science must get better.

title: Rebuilding Trust in Science
content: We need to be prepared to not use all the rhetorical tools at our disposal at any one point in time to convince somebody that X is true. We need to elevate our societal norms of dialogue on epistemological and empirical issues. So that ordinary people can say, “Oh, you’re telling me you have a treatment for X. Was there a study? Was the study in humans? Was it a randomized study? Was it a study of the actual outcome you’re making a claim about? Was it a study that was long enough for this to be a meaningful outcome? Was there a statistically significant result? Was the result big enough to matter? Was the dose a dose I might realistically take?”

title: Trust in Science and Health Professionals
content: Trust in science is high, trust in dieticians is high, trust in medical doctors who talk about nutrition in treating their patients is high. But trust in nutrition scientists is low compared to dieticians and medical doctors who talk about nutrition, and compared to other scientists. This trust issue is due to obfuscation, exaggeration, and hype in the field of nutrition.

title: Difference Between Science and Advocacy
content: The difference between science and advocacy can’t be overstated. The scientist hat is focused on the nuanced hard truth, as messy as it might be, as unclear as it might be, with no regard for how a person feels when they hear it and what action they may or may not take as a result of it. This is different from the advocacy hat which is saying, 'I want to change your behavior because I think it’s in your best interest.'
